name: Nihilumbra
description: Discover the beautiful world of Nihilumbra and join Born on his adventure to find himself whilst trying to escape from his inevitable curse. Born was created from the absolute nothingness: The Void. But somehow he separates himself from the black emptiness and appears in the world.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/7 Processor: 1.6 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Storage: 3 GB available space

reviews.review_text: “Ew, a mobile game getting a PC port? No thanks!” You might say. But wait! Not all portable titles are games with simple yet addictive mechanics looking to take your money. Nihilumbra is a neat little puzzle platformer from Spanish developer Beautifun Games. You take control of Born, a creature created by The Void, who escapes to the real world. Relentlessly pursued by that which created him, Born treks across new and strange environments, discovering what it truly means to be alive.  He isn’t the only being from The Void that has crossed over however. Every now and then you will encounter a new enemy, each more dangerous than the last. These, combined with various environmental hazards provide much of the challenge outside of the platforming. The jumping itself isn’t complex, but as the game progresses you will discover new colours which can be painted on the walls, ceilings and ground of the levels. The game has five separate worlds, and there is a colour tied to each of them. The Frozen Hills grants you blue, a colour to make surfaces icy, helping you run faster or push previously unmovable objects. The Living Forest gives you green, allowing you to make surfaces bouncy. The Ash Desert provides brown, which makes anything you paint it on sticky. The Volcano grants you red, which heats up surfaces to burn objects and enemies alike. Finally, The City unlocks yellow, which conducts electricity, allowing you to link electrical objects together. Thankfully the controls translate to keyboard and mouse perfectly. Painting is as simple as left clicking and dragging, and doing the same with right click acts as an eraser. Although the game is 2D, the first two colours in particular have a very Portal 2-esque feel about them. You will be using momentum to jump and bounce your way to new platforms, and although it sometimes lacks precision, it isn’t all that frustrating. You will often use multiple colours in the same puzzle. For example you might use yellow to activate a powerful electromagnet, lifting your enemies into the air. Using brown on the floor in front of you allows you to walk along underneath them without being attracted yourself. There are a good amount of well thought out puzzles here. None of them take particularly long to figure out though. The game as a whole is not all that hard, and can be completed in a few hours at most – an unfortunate leftover from the fast paced mobile platform it was born on. Nihilumbra employs a simple, yet effective art style. Each level has its own colourful theme, often attempting to give you a feel of the heat of the area. The icy areas are very blue, and the volcano is red, for obvious reasons, but this also related to the story. As Born uncovers new colours he begins to feel warmer inside, as if The Void inside him is being filled. The main character himself begins as an amorphous blob, but upon entering the real world he decides to change himself to try and blend in. The first thing he encounters is a scarecrow however, so you spend the rest of the game naively jumping around as a cute, raggedy old shadow creature. The character design of the Void enemies is good too, with weird plant creatures which launch projectiles at you, and a huge snail-like thing that erases any colours it slithers over.  At the end of each world, there is a fast paced platforming section where you are being chased by The Void. Ever encroaching from the left of the screen, you simply have to stay ahead of it and reach the end. These are some of the weakest sections of the game, as it shows off the lack of accuracy the platforming has at times. Switching between colours quickly is cumbersome, especially when attempted at speed. I would have liked the action to pause when bringing up the colour menu, as I often got caught out without the colour I needed. Thankfully the game is liberally checkpointed, even in the normal levels, so you never lose much progress. These checkpoints also seem to return all of your colour to you. It feels as if you are using some sort of resource when painting, but this was never explained, and I never ran out, so I can’t be sure. All in all, Nihilumbra is a short, but fun, puzzle platformer. The puzzles you encounter aren’t all that difficult, but they do require some thought, particular in later stages. The platforming itself isn’t all that good, but the unique painting mechanics make up for it. Mobile games are becoming more complex, and simply better overall, and it is nice to see that some of the higher quality ones are making the switch over to PC.
Never before have I sympathized so much for, literally, a character who is nothingness. ;-;
Nihilumbra is an excellent indie platformer.

Nihilumbra is a poetic 2D platform game. In my opinion, it's very similar to Limbo, but the game also made me think about Another World and Heart Of Darkness for the design, the level-design and the gameplay. The poetic side of the game is reinforced by the off-voice of the narrator in almost every screen of the story mode. The story mode is not very difficult, and its main purpose is to tell a poetic story, the birth of the protagonist from the void, and his discovery of our world through different and various landscapes. The gameplay is based on the mastering of colours, which have different properties, such as the possibility to slide, or to bounce, etc...  Once you've finished the story mode, you unlock the void mode. Here, forget about the story, the poetism and the narration, it's all about thinking, skill and timing. The void mode visits all levels of the story mode once again and modifies them into much harder puzzle levels. It's somehow like the dark world in Super Meat Boy, but in a more easier way though.  I had a good time with this game, and I recommend it to every Limbo-like lovers.  Nihilumbra has just one big problem : its length. It'll take you about 3 hours (maximum) to finish the story mode, and maybe the double to beat the void mode, depending on your skills.
Wonderful platformer with a good story whilst using an interesting mechanic for advancing from level to level.   I'd also like to hire that voice in the game to narrate my entire life.

The game title pretty much sums up the game content ; Nihilumbra is the union of two latin words, Nihil ( Nothing ) and Umbra ( Shadow ) ---> you're a shadow made of nothing,literally. Your main goal in this action game is to survive and avoid your natural enemy,which is also your philosophical father, 'The Void' or Death,call it how you want. The game will reveal its best aspect when played in New Game+,known also as 'Void Mode'. This game has a nice longevity ( 13-14 hours ) and it will surely pleasure your eyes. The gameplay is solid; your charachter will gain new and new abilities troughout the entire game.  Note that this game deals with philosophical issues like death,nihilism and hope.  This game is a little pearl,touch it with silken gloves.
Fantastic game, change the world and solve puzzles with colors, at the same time you get to discover the reason of your own existence!
This game is pretty cool, trippy and colorful. I recommend it for casual gamers :)

Just Finished Nihilumbra today ! I will have to beat hard mode now, but I really enjoyed it,the music suits perfectly the game ,there's such a nice ambience, the all game is beautiful and very poetic. I strongly recommand it. GG @BeautiFunGames !

Nihilumbra has a defined art style, strives for narrative, and deals whimsically with depression. But its narrative does come off as a touch preachy and its narrator is not entirely interesting. There’s also the problem of game play. Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer with few solid puzzles and irritating platforming that consists of predetermined stages of play. These areas shift as you move along instead of the screen following your character. It’s off-putting at first then it becomes truly annoying as you die to enemies situated directly out of your view or you have to take leaps of faith. The game doesn’t advertise itself with the game play though, but ultimately what it does claim to have falls short. There is great potential here, but it falls short.   Nihilumbra has a good name, interesting art, and a nice soundtrack… That’s about it really. If you like those things go for it. If not, I can’t recommend it.

Very creative and an excellent story. The puzzles are challenging while still being fun. The initial story is short, but there is another story mode after you beat the game with even more difficult puzzles. I would give this game a 9/10, with its only downfall being its length.

Nihilumbra is both a very interesting and very divided game. It was presented to me as 'Limbo meets Portal,' but in practice, I found it to be like neither of these things. The unfitting dark creatures roaming about the relatively normal environments felt more like Heart of Darkness, and the emphasis on the 'paint mechanic' (there are no portals) gives it more similarities to Tag: The Power of Paint. I was also told that the game made figurative waves on the iOS market, but that is a market so inundated with inane and uninteresting nonsense that the comment meant exactly nothing to me, so I went about my playthrough of Nihilumbra determined not to give it a free pass for standing out from mediocrity. So let's get to it.  I said that I felt that the game was divided. The gameplay is divided into two distinct modes, the story mode, and the void mode. The latter is unlocked after completing the former. The story mode is what you'd expect; it tells the story. The biggest problem people will have with the story mode is the narrator, or more specifically, the narration design. The decision to have a narrator in a game about nihilism is questionable. I'd think silent, empty text would serve the presentation much better, so that's what I went with when I played it. I don't think the voice is necessarily terrible, but I don't think the presence of a voice in this game is necessarily warranted, either. The narration is also triggered by your position on the different screens within the levels, and if you die and return to a checkpoint, the narration will repeat every time, and this can get grating. Fortunately, for the people who will be too lazy to mute the narration, the story mode is almost too easy.  Void mode is the game's answer to that. It's the obligatory, 'you can't spell 'indie' without 'die'' departure from the almost insultingly easy story mode. This section of the game is of a very much 'Oddworldian' difficulty. There is plenty of trial and error to go with the more challenging puzzles. You will die in void mode. I've seen void mode criticized a lot, but again, these are (mostly) iPad gamers we're talking about. Fortunately, you are given a reprieve from the narration, but this can be both good and bad. You are introduced to void mode with the promise of closure to the game's somewhat bitter epilogue (What? Did you expect a good ending in a game about nihilism? DID YOU?). While you do technically get that closure, it's accompanied with absolutely no narration or text, so it's a bit of a dull reward for anyone who played through void mode because they liked the story and wanted that elusive happy ending. The only other thing you get (besides the achievements and accompanying bragging rights) is a 'secret language,' which changes the text of the narration and makes it the complete antithesis of taking itself seriously, so if you thought the story was pretentious garbage, hated it and want some cheap catharsis, you might enjoy replaying story mode for that, but it will just end up leaving a bad taste in everyone else's mouths, especially with the internet memes which have basically already made the 'humor' rather dated.  There is appeal to be had in both the story mode and the void mode, but I think the whole package kind of antagonizes itself. I don't see many people enjoying the whole of the game. Most people will probably heavily prefer one half over the other, and people who prefer the story mode will have to settle with the bitter ending, and people who prefer void mode will have to trudge through the story mode. Whether you decide this game is worth it to you or not will depend on which of those two types of people you decide you are, and whether you feel that you'll only enjoy one half of the game.
Nice puzzle-platformer with philosophical story. Better to play it on iOS, but on PC this good too.
Quite short, but longer would be boring. Very easy gameplay, but the story and how it deliveres it´s message to the player. A small, but really nice game. There is nothing I would critizise here.

A very fantastic game with lots of fun puzzles. I just love the design of the main character, concept of the enimies, and even the levels.  If you aren't into puzzles, it still makes for a great platforming game. Bravo, I really recomend this game to my friends. 10/10

This game is such a gem. The gameplay alone makes it a worthwhile purchase, but the true beauty of this game is in the sound and design. The best way I can think to describe the music is that it's something reminiscent of Danny Elfman, Edward Scissorhands in particular. The narrator speaks to you on your journey, making for quite the immersive start and then some. The best thing has to be how this game makes you think - and I don't mean with puzzles, though it will certainly do that. I believe the game must be a metaphor for how small and insignificant humans feel on the Earth, and about trying to attain some sort of meaning. The void will always find you... 10/10
Beautiful imagery, stellar soundtrack and tragic storyline. It's well worth if you enjoy interactive puzzles, and are a fan of 'platformers.'
i don't remember why i bought this, but im happy i did

Going from normal to void mode was like jumping from kindergarten to college....  With that being said I think the mood and soundtrack work well to create a unique atmosphere to set the foreboding tone of the overall game. Well worth playing even though its a seemingly quick play through

Brilliant puzzle platformer with a nice soundtrack. It is very insightful and has fun gameplay elements that involve manipulating the physics of the world around you using different colors to proceed through levels avoiding obstacles, traps, and monsters. If you choose to play the void mode, be prepared for a stiff challenge. The main game itself is not too hard if you are looking for a relaxing platformer with eye candy graphics.

A dark and dangerous adventure filled with beautiful imagery and a sense of playfulness hinted at behind the miserable facade. Nihilumbra is an exciting and moody platformer that should interest casual and hardcore gamers alike.   As Born, use the different elements acquired to traverse the obstacles given and avoid being absorbed by The Void.  A hardcore version of the game is unlocked upon completion, called 'Void Mode'. It is essentially the same game, albiet with design differences in each level as well as a drastic spike in difficulty.  9.5/10 Highly Recommended for fans of the Platformer Genre.
A great platformer/puzzler with a unique art style and gameplay. Void mode is HARD, but doable. But still, HARD in parts.  Highly recommend.
This was a very fun game to play through. It was challenging at some parts, but it wasn't a difficult game overall.  My only complaint was that the story seemed too short.
Realy visually appealing and a nice story. Kinda paranoia inducing at first but it gets better.

I bought it just to get the insignia but I didn't expect how artistic the game is. It's enchanting and calming, it teaches a lesson and if you pay attention you can easily realize that the game talks about the depression. It was a great experience doing the story mode.

Quaint little puzzle game that revolves around using colors with certain advantages to progress your quest. The puzzles are quite simple and aren't too hard to solve until the second playthrough. Really the journey is the story being told that both beats you down and lifts you up in incredible ways.  Easy game to get 100% completion if you're looking for some more perfect games. 7/10

Loved this game, I was skeptical at first but was immediately drawn in. Its fun platformer where you use different colors to solves puzzles. The game gets more intresting as you gain more colors with different abilities. I only wanted to try it out and ended up beating the game in one sitting. Its about 3 hours of gameplay and there's a void mode after completion if youre looking for a real challenge. I recommend you get this game if you love platformers or puzzles and if its on sale since it isnt too long.

The game is quite nice and generally I'd recommend it, but ...     Story mode is too easy    The narraror in story mode is only for the very depressed,    I really don't know what this talking about 'guilt' is all about, it's just annoying.       Some levels in void mode can bee very hard, there is no way to adjust difficulty.     impossible to remap keys     it is not a real side-scroller, so often when you move to a new screen you are confronted with a situation that will kill you and you'll have to redo everything from the last save point to enter this screen prepared. Often the sitation that is presented is not really hard to resolve if only you would have had a chance to see it half a second before. Or maybe that's just me being slow ... In void mode this can become  very  annoying. Well, at least there is an achievement for dying 10 times in a row in void mode ;)    Apart from that it is fun to play.

Get born, get colors, get smart.  Enjoyable casual puzzles for story mode, hair-pulling conundrums in Void mode.  Awesome soundtrack and effects, the narration was great at setting the mood.  Beautiful backdrops and art. The story is prose like.  Gameplay time currently at 5 hours after story mode, probably 15-16 on completion. Will update review.  Worth the buy.

There are a lot of nit picky things that you could say about this game. Like the fact that you can't use your mouse roller to choose diffrent colors so in the middle of trying to stop a red color from killing you, you must go to the corner and click the purple and in trying to do that the red color burns you to death. Then you have to go to the last check point which in most cases is very far away from where you were. What makes that more frustrateing is that the check point that would have saved you was two feet away.   But then there are some really annoying things about it like the fact that if you die and there is a point where the narrator talk he will repeat it and if you die a lot he will repeat it AGAIN AND AGAIN. Is the narrator suppost to be my conscious? He would always say stuff like 'You should feel bad' 'You feel guilt' it was kinda like gauntlet where the wizard says PLAYER 2 IS HUNGRY. Except the wizard only said that when it was necessary not every 2 seconds.   It was like the narrator was trying to make me feel bad for this little black thing that had no personality or backstory.And he kept trying to remind you that HEY DONT FORGET TO FEEL AWFUL. Sometimes he would blatenly say something along the lines of you should just kill yourself because you were 'ruining' the places you were leaving behind.   The puzzles are not challangeing and the monsters in the game make inovative and new ways to solve them impossible and they are so repetitive that you die 3000 times before you can get to the next checkpoint. Sometimes there is a part of the void that is plastared onto the scenery so it is impossible to try new ways to solve the puzzles. The scenery is bland and the game itself is very repetitive. There is no real story at all to it except to run away from the void. No reason to why I want to do this no reason to why I am in the places I am. It was cute at first but then it just got annoying and was no longer fun to play and had absolutly no replay value. It had a lot of potential and I was really excited to play it but in the end it was not worth the money.

Personally, this is one of the most touching games I've played this year. Even if there is no direct interaction between the character and the player (bar the obvious control), this game has connected me with Born, a young, child-like being that simply wanted to do what we all do - live.  A random, cheap title which sparked my interest with its unusual, yet seductive title. Guess you shouldn't judge a book by its cover.

Amazingly good game!  Has some pretty good lessons to teach the player, gameplay is good. Especially after completing the initial section!  Artwork is great, just overall a really amazing sleeper title!  8/10!

One of the most beautiful games I've ever played, aside from LIMBO, with it's restricted colour palette and the sound of nothing but puzzles and footsteps  It's simple yet complicated in design, It may not be graphically gorgeous but it is emotionally. I really enjoyed playing this game throughout. The puzzles are simple yet fun to complete and there are a few frustrating ones. 10/10 Would recommend for players who wish to play a gentle puzzle game with a backstory.  Has a pretty sweet soundtrack too.

Should probably caution on the fact that:  1) the game is very short (I beat it in 2 hours, this is without the challenge modes though).  2) the game is very easy (minus the challenge modes).  Now with those out of the way, let me say that Nihilumbra could be a hidden gem. It's just as good as some of the other indie greats like FEZ, Braid, or even Super Meat Boy (except, again, this game is way easier than those). The game makes use an intresting macanic where you paint surfaces with different colors that all have different effects - somewhat reminds me of Portal. If you want a game with logic puzzle like Portal (minus the humor though because this game gets somewhat depressing) and are okay with a short length like Portal then this game is for you.   Although I say the game is easy, the Challenge mode after beating the game really is hard, but I still feel like the game is only giving me the difficultys of 'Press A to win' Easy, and 'Start the game to die' Hard.
Alt-F4-Factor = high, but nevertheless a great game (8/10).

Well... There is one big question: For who is this game?  When I first started it, my first opinion was 'oh okay not kids' but further I developed and listening to more to narrator I wasn't sure anymore about this... and well thats really the thing I don't like about this game...  It did not satisfy me... The game control is in my opinion not very well thought out... and well if you played the first part of the game there is no need for this, true! But come on... in the second part of the game it gets so much harder... it could be made better... Also I think the hitradio is sometimes redicules...The graphics and the narrator are very well! But somehow nothing new and so spectacular that made the game 'ok'...  I really credit the gamedevelopers for making it! But it bothers me for who... a child who should learn perspectif about life? (well not with this strong words and complex gameplay...) a teenager? (well yeah could be! but I don't think they will be interessted for long...) an adult? interesting concept but there are some annoying collision bugs

I wanted to like this game, but there's just too much wrong with it.  Pros: - Cool concept - Interesting graphics  Cons: - Really short - Terrible camera - Lots of cheap deaths (mostly because of the terrible camera) - Switching powers is clunky (thus causing more cheap deaths) - Puzzles are way too easy. - The narrator is one of the worst I've ever heard.  If you really must get this game, wait until it's on sale. And do yourself a favor: mute the narrator.

Simply put, I really did not like this game. Many of my complaints are mirrored by other reviewers. The narrator's voice is not very well acted, very repetitious, very trite, and just...constant. He shows up with zingers about finding your heart, how anger is dangerous, how it's important to feel sadness, and at times I found myself blinking in disbelief that the lines made it through to the final draft.   The gameplay is mediocre. It isn't outright bad, but it's just not very fun. You spend most of your time trying out different powers, which will give you the ability to: slide yourself and objects over ground, toast things (including you if you're not careful) with raging fires, make the ground 'bouncy' so everything springs off of it, create electricity to turn on circuits (and thus make puzzles 'run' their active elements), and a few others I'm probably forgetting. That's the thing - the abilities are really just forgettable. Platforming staples like 'bouncy bouncy' need a little twist to make them interesting. Otherwise you are just back to Mario and spring-boards again.   Personally, I found the story tedious and unoriginal. You play as a sliver of the void, inexplicably cast onto the earth, and running from the 'void' - an understandably featureless foe who chases you across the map on occasion, and summons minions to try and slay you in a few different ways. The rule in this game is Insta-Death, which would be fun and exciting if the monsters were not so often acting in entirely novel ways, reacting unpredictably to tiny mistakes on your behalf (e.g. missing a small spot on the floor with the 'paint-on' effects), or just being RIGHT THERE as you enter a new frame. They also tend to have (IMO) awkward hit-boxes, such that you think you are okay springing over them, only to mysteriously die when you get too close.  I finished the main game in a little over two hours. It's a decently priced game, and I don't have much to complain about here. There is a 'void' mode unlocked after beating the main game, but I found the game suddenly veered from stupidly easy, to stupidly hard when I reached this mode - I never found the game reached that 'sweet spot' for me, between the two poles. I found myself, ridiculously, stuck on the very first 'room' of Void mode, perfectly able to solve the 'puzzle' (jumping over a charging enemy by building a little altitude), and occasionally succeeding (only to die on the next room) but almost entirely unable to execute it.   Trading Cards are a nice perk, and I sold them for an effective $1 reduction in price.  Achievements are what you would expect. About half are for clearing levels and winning the game, or objectives you can't avoid completing. The other are fairly obscure, and I believe there is a handful of hidden ones. Nothing too staggering here, but par for the course.  Overall, I disliked this game, and would probably rate it something like 4/10. It wasn't pull-out-your-hair bad, but on reflection, I think it was not worth the money. A couple hours wasted, no harm done, but nothing I can give a 'thumb up' to with a good conscience.

This is a good game. I've thought about this for a while and decided to still not recommend the game. It's good, but not amazing. The art is excellent, the story is decent, the gameplay is reasonable, the animation ok. There's nothing overly wrong with the game, but I didn't feel overly compelled to continue when playing through it. It wasn't quite challenging enough for me (not necessarily a problem), but perhaps it was a bit too slow for its difficulty. This wasn't a game that I was sad when I completed it since I couldn't play it any more. I was content at the end, but that's about it. Note that I did not play new game+ since I personally had enough. Maybe I would have liked it more if it started with hard mode as an option, but that still might not be enough to merit a recommendation from me.

If you can get this on sale it's worth trying out, the first part of the game is fun, if a little easy. I enjoyed it.  It's the 'Void Mode' that unlocks after the credits that's terrible, because of the poor puzzle design. It's just a mixture of trial and error traps where you have to know what to do beforehand to be able to do it quickly enough, and puzzles where you spend several minutes setting up the solution only to die during the execution of it because your timing was a half-second off, then the whole thing resets and you have to do it all again.  From what little I experienced, it seems like Void Mode is the meat of the game, expected to take a lot longer than the first part. Which would be good, just a shame it isn't the good kind of difficult.  Edit: I did enjoy how the programmers in the credits were listed starting from 'Programmer 0' :v

This is one of the loveliest gams I've ever played. I'm more of a casual gamer, but this game completely gripped me from the start, and I couldn't rest until I'd finished it. It' haunting and beautiful, and I think it' probably my favourite of any game I've ever played. Still attempting to wade my way through Void mode, which I am finding a lt more dificult than the main game, but I'd definitly play it again.

I hate puzzle games. This is hard. I'm going back to shooting zombies now. Thanks to the awesome art gallery the game stays rewarding even after the main story is finished.

The playthrough can be divided into two main stages. Casual - ~2h main story mode where you learn about your abilities and about puzzles. There is narration, feels, thoughts etc. When you finish this mode the game unlocks the 'void mode', which is a more difficult mode which tests your understanding of the mechanics. Progressing in the void mode unlocks more stuff in the art gallery, which actually is a nice reward. The art is a strong side of this game. I'm glad you can even see designer scetches when you unlock that.  Thoughts: I wasn't very comfortable with the controls (and the mechanics). Initial momentum is very important, you don't get much control mid-air. Levels are divided into screens. I get a feeling that this decision was brought up very late, as beating some screens requires speeding up from an area on another screen. I wish this game used the classic side-scrolling model. The narrator began to annoy me a little after some time (he sounded a little monotonic). Also after respawning at a checkpoint a few times the narrator reads the same lines every time, which is also getting annoying after a few times. Art is an important aspect of games like this. Progressing unlocks more entries in the art gallery, which in my opinion is a good reward (there are also achievements, which add replayability value). While the story mode is beatable in short time, I'm sure the void mode will take a lot more time to beat as it is more puzzle-and-mechanics based.  So, should you get it? It's an interesting position. Made me a little emotional actually. The art and music fit well together. The narrator says some things that actually make you think about life and death a little. If you're looking for something like that - go for it. If you're looking for a challenging platformer then I'd recommend something else. This game takes away some control from the player.

I recommend this game in spite of some irritating gamebreaking bugs. *hint* something about balls not going far enough The game's pretty easy until you beat it, by which you unlock 'Void Mode' which spices it up a bit. Overall fun game.

I dont like the gameplay that much but the amazing allegory in the game is what makes this game fantastic!

I liked Nihilumbra, it really gets the mind working! The first run through of the game is easy. After that, there's the Void mode, when the game really gets tough. Makes the first part feel like a tutorial.

I really liked Nihilumbra. The story, though short, was interesting. The gameplay was fun. I was up for hours after my bedtime beating it in one go.

I havent played it for some time, and wanted to dwell on my thoughts of it before writing this. Because this game isnt just some quick play through in a few hours thoughtless run right platformer. I mean you do run endlessly right, and you do jump alot, but its so much more. It takes the legacy built upon for virtually the entire life of action sprite based side scrollers and takes it to something eye catchingly lovely while making you summon up the hand eye twitch skills that for many of us older gamers will take us back to the 80s and even before compared to many modern games that seem to cater to our ever aging and more casual needs.  This game has story, that is a pleasure to hear the narration of as you flee from the very stuff you are born of. You now seek to LIVE fully and embrace the world in all its colors. You must keep one step ahead of that which you now must avoid at all cost, and gird yourself in the energies of life to move ever more effectively and even defeat those things which dare to bar your path. But in the end this is not a story of bringing meaningless death to masses of foes, no this is a game about bringing back life to a world that nearly dies for the price of your experiencing it.
great story!!

A must-play, state-of-art puzzle game with great replay value (achievements as well as 'beat the game once again, harder' mode). Great music and philosophy. Nihilumbra is one of this kind of games, which are not just games, but something more. Definitely recommended.
Why is this game on my computer? It belongs on a wall, with a pretty frame.

Challenging, atmospheric, meaningful and immersive; all that describes Nihilumbra.  Many know this game as an iOS port, but it is definitely best played on PC. You play as a piece of void, who craves to seek the world beyond darkness -- and this game really delivers the emotions of the voidling through the narration of the 'voice inside your head'.  It is quite short, however, but very thought provoking. Consider the first time you finish the game as your  tutorial  for the challenge mode that comes next: The Void Mode. So the game never stops challenging you with harder and harder levels.  A great buy, especially if you purchase on a sale.

Wonderful game with gorgious art and well thought out mechanic. Normal mode is pretty easy but Void mode... wow that's difficult. I love how the 5 colors tie into the areas they're from. Blue makes you go fast since it's from the icy mountains, green makes you bounce since it's from the jungle, brown is sticky since it's from the desert, red burns things like lava, and yellow directs electricity in the city. Only thing I wish is the ability to TURN OFF THAT DAMN NARRATOR! After hearing his voice several time repeating the same line I was irritated.

Very beatiful piece of art. The first time you go through it, it is mostly a story telling game, and i simply loved living this adventure. Very deep. Another good aspect is the fantasy it relases, you have to wisely use your 'colors', which have different powers, to go through the game. In normal mode it isn't that difficult, but in 'void mode', unlocked once finishing the game, heck, it becomes really difficult! The art works are fascinating and catching, the narrator voice is like your only fellow in your odissey, the music and the atmosphere are really involving and will make you want to get to the end of the game, the end of the story, the end of the suffering?!  In conclusion, i'd reccomend this game to ones who like challenging puzzle games, or good story telling ones

First off, I cant say i have play all too much of Nihilumbra but i did however beat the main story on normal with a bit of hard mode. In the art department the game is defenatly somthing you wont see anywhere else (i personaly like it but wouldent say its the best i have seen) so if thats your sort of thing then it defenatly is not lacking. the gameplay is responsive and smooth, the elements take a while to unlock and getting them is a bit anoying at times but it isent detracting from the overall experence too much. the story is interesting and i realy like it, i will try to give a overall picture of the start of the story here. there is a void being that is having an exostential crisis of sorts that is getting chased down and has to escape its grasp. so yep thats my review kinda all over the place but it is what it is.  over all its a fun little puzzel game that wont last too long if you dont go into hard mode and beyond but a good purchase at $8 none the less.  6.5/10

Really a beatiful little game.   -The art style is very nice,  -the story is cute,  -the controls feel fluid and responsive.  -The voice acting is fantastic  However  -It is rather short -The platforming and puzzles arn't paticularly difficult  This is definatly a game to get if you're looking for a cute little narritive and a lovely art style, but if you're looking for a long and challenging game I'd say to avoid it.

A good fun game, thought provoking (Which isn't found in many indie games). Isn't bogged down with unnecessary cut scenes and character. Simple, challenging (but not too hard). Definately reccomend. 10/10
Very nice game, it manages to integrate gameplay and narration/story. Very recommended.
Very tasty game, well done :tup:

I can appreciate and understand the message they wish to convey, however, that being said, they take a typical approach, with very little thought put into its design. The art, although stylized, felt rushed, the story which tried to be engaging, was both unoriginal and rushed. I found the puzzles to be very predictable and hardly engaging, There was no real rewarding feeling you do not identify with born and the narrator at times is too slow, and can even just be an annoyance. Very short game, with poor gameplay and predictable story, a great example of what not to do in game design. I can clearly see its inspirations and its overall goal however the approach taken was wrong. The ending felt almost like a 'what' moment, where in teh beginning it was eluded too, tehn forgotten, then brought back. If youre buying this solely for the story mode, then dont waste your time, overall a 6/10, but for the price, those are my only complaints.
This game gives me feels. The kind of feely feels that feel..Feely.

A great artsy indie puzzle platformer that still manages to stand apart from all the other great artsy indie puzzle platformers. Simple, yet clever mechanics, a thoughtful story, great music, and a nice challenging endgame. Give it a shot.

A nice side scroller that kept me playing throughout the story. Even after beating the game, there is the 'void mode' which is a hard mode unlocked after beating the game. The gameplay itself is fun, using colors with unique abilities to solve your puzzles. Another great fact is our dutiful narrorator, who speaks to you as if an inner monologue throughout the game. If this game is on sale, or if you are really interested, buy it.

What's the point of living if you are going to die at hte end? Does it have any purpose? is it worth it to keep struggling, day by day?  These are the words that spur you on as you learn about the world around you, being drawn into the amazing realms you explore, all while trying to avoid the void, who wishes to invite you back into it's lifeless bossom. This simple puzzle platformer doesn't take that long to complete (for me about 3 and 1/2 hours) but was worth every moment. Even completed I plan to do it again, for the messages hidden here, really draw you along.

The art is pretty. The story is fairly short, but has a couple of nice ideas in it. The void mode is really challenging. They manage to get all three (visuals, interesting ideas/story, challenge) into the game. Satisfying to whizz through the story and yet still lots to do afterwards.

Very atmoshperic game with an interesting art style. Some of the parts of the game really build some psychological tension, especially if there is Void that approaches behind you. You travel the world and acquire new powers to help your wits in some puzzles. After first playthrough you can replay the levels again to clear the corrupted levels. They are slightly harder and different now. You also unlock extra pictures in the gallery. The music is moody and voice acting is great. Overall, I really liked the game. Buy it if you like unique indie puzzle platfromers.
An oddly satisfying game. Very good in presentation, maybe a bit let down in asanine puzzles in the postgame.

A lot of folks from what I hear haven't really expressed much good-favor for this game. Well I'm glad you stumbled your way here because I'm about to do the opposite of that. This game...I doubt any words I say could do it justice, but lemme tell ya, this game is a fine piece of art. The artwork, character designs, music, and the story are all very wonderful and gorgeous. I'd totally recommend this game because it's astonishingly beautiful, and interesting to play. You should check out the soundtrack too, I think it's definitely worth it because the music is just so amazing. This whole game is amazing, and I love it!

This is the true hidden gem of platformers. You control a being from the void, trying to escape it. Along the way, you encounter colors which have special properties like bouncy or sliding. The main story mode isn't really the most difficult thing, Nihilumbra is made to be atmospheric, travelling in an empty world with only danger in the paths ahead. It's a great game, and if you finished the main story, you can play void mode, which will put your skills and brain to the test. It is really amazing, and I'd highly reccommend it to both casual gamers and hardcore gamers

While very neat aesthetically, the narrator quickly became annoying and presumptuous about the player's actions and should have avoided using 'you' and 'your' or given more options as I quickly felt disconected from my blob and all the emotions claimed felt incredibly forced and, like the void, empty.   Dificulty wise I found the main game to be a giant tutorial and upon trying the post-game 'void mode' found it was both the real meat of the game but sadly left a bitter taste in my mouth and I have no real want to complete it. The game lacks a dificulty curve and goes from mind numbingly easy to dreadfully dificult with no real middleground. Many deaths seem to require forsight to bypass on a first try or be up to luck. Thankfully, in the main game this is mitigated by frequent checkpoints and while not so great design wise is quickly forgotten. In Void mode however, the game feels like platformer romhack design in that there is a lot of waiting, needless spikes for precision platforming in long puzzle areas, and the oppening has you face to face with an enemy and flat terrain and is just an awful introduction to the mode that left me feeling 'Really game?'.   While I do have negative complaints, let them not be the entirety of my view on the game aside from aesthetics. I enjoyed the combination of platform and painting puzzle elements and I would like to see more done in this vein without resorting to the void mode levels of dificulty! There are amazing ideas at work here and I think they are more in need of fine tuning and dificulty balancing than being anywhere near outright bad. I hope to see more from these devs in the future, and hope they improve along the way!

The game feels like a better version of Limbo. Timing can be critical but I've been more patient with this 'trial and error' king of game. The story and music are pretty cool. Void Mode is unlocked by beating the main game. Void Mode is very hard.
Nice game.

This is a beautiful game with a stirring atmosphere and mood. A puzzle-platformer at it's core, it is immersive enough to make you forget that you're solving puzzles or dodging strange other-wordly creatures but feels more like a story that you're enjoying and experiencing.  I don't play many puzzle games and I still loved it so don't overlook this game because of the puzzle factor! I found the puzzles to be just right - they were sufficiently rewarding and never too frustrating to solve. The platforming is pretty straight forward and enhanced by some of the unique abilities the protagonist acquires (eg: being able to shoot a sticky-mud thing onto walls to cling onto or shooting bouncy grass or ice to reach sections otherwise inaccessible. There's some nice creativity at the core of this game.  Once you complete the main story (arguably not quite a 'story' in the traditional sense but still immensely enjoyable...) you unlock a harder version of the game - same areas with more complex puzzles. These, I safely avoided due to my aforetold indifference to hardcore puzzle games but that does add good replay value and may strike a chord with the puzzler in you.  In all - this is an excellent Indie title. You can even try the demo from the developer's website I believe if you're on the fence.  PS: IIRC I spent more than the 3.5 hours reported by Steam on this game (probably spent offline) but in any case this is a short game without any doubt, so bear that in mind.
Better than I expected..

Fun little platformer with a beatiful soundtrack and fantastic visuals. The main campaign has a very fair learning curve, but is unfortunately only about 2 hours long. After completing that, a second campaign, called 'Void Mode' opens up, where the difficulty scales up rather significantly. I have no idea how long this second campaign is though, as I currently can't get past the first level without looking up a walkthough. At the time of this review, the game is on sale for $2, and at that price I would call it a must-play.

A really nice game! I really reccomend it, don't even think about buying it! Just do it!  Overall, Nice story, gameplay, artwork and idea aswell.

I haven't yet played Void Mode, but after completing the main story here are my impressions. The levels are short but sweet with frequent checkpoints - even if you have trouble adjusting to the controls you never get sent back too far. The music is wonderful and does an excellent job at setting the mood of each area. Although I've never been a fan of auto-scrolling, especially while being chased by an invincible hazard, I found myself looking forward to the void segments the most. They're easy enough that I didn't find them frustrating at all.  One problem I had is that at times I found myself overthinking the puzzles and making them harder for myself than they really are. The solutions are always fairly simple, and the frequent checkpoints mean that even if you have trouble and die several times you're able to try again almost immediately. That being said, this game is suitable for any skill level and isn't hard to learn to play. Highly recommended.
Time to kill myself. 8/10    will go into the void again.

Beautiful and pretty fun. Avante-garde, minimalist storytelling. Great play mechanics, and the handful of tough puzzles are rewarding. I wish there were more intricate puzzles, but overall I'm satisfied.
I had fun while playing this game. Sure, the story left me with a feeling of 'meh, could be better', but the Void mode was challenging and entertaining.
A cute simple game that will make you rage 9.5/10

I recommend if you like puzzle platformers or simple, almost casual, platformers.  The good: Nice artstyle, nice mechanics, a feel-good story, good music.  The Bad: Too short, feels like an introduction to each mechanic and not a fully fleshed out game, pretentious narrator (although he has a good voice)

This was a really great game in my opinion. And apparently it's a port of a mobile game. I had absolutely no idea until after I finished playing through it. Honestly, it really did fool me. Anyways, I think this game is amazing! I think the story and narration is really great, the puzzles are good for the most part, and I loved the style and mechanics of it all. The only complaint I would have is Void Mode. After you beat the game, you unlock Void Mode, which is basically hard mode. In Void Mode, the puzzles range from fairly easy to nearly impossible, either because it's difficult to figure it out, or you know exactly what to do, except you have to execute nearly perfectly. Not to mention that at the end, the game basically says, 'Hey you should go do Void Mode' and I was hoping for like a cutscene or something, but nope. Although it does reward you for beating it, I was kind of disappointed. Although, I would still recommend the game at least for the main story, and if you're looking for a challenge, Void Mode is for you

I initially bought this game just because it was on sale, but it turned out to be one of the more imaginative games i've seen in a while. As soon as the game started, I was thrown into a world of beautiful artwork and music. I also loved the main character, despite it being little more than a blob. The narrator (whose voice resembles that of Morgan Freeman) plays very well into the overall atmosphere, which can vary from charming to downright unsettleing. This is an amazing indie game that obviosly had a lot of love put into it and deserves more attention. My only complaint is that the puzzles leave something to be desired, as I solved most of them almost instantly. Overall, I'd give this game 4/5 stars

The first playthrough is only around 2.5 hours and is fun and mildly/comfortably challenging, but the second playthrough in Void Mode is where the game shines (challenge-wise). While Void Mode goes through the same landscapes, the puzzles are different: Braid/Portal levels of complexity/challenge (judging from the first 6% I've played of it so far), and I get the feeling this mode will take at least twice as long to finish, so at least 8 hours' worth of fun gameplay.   It has a basic story, which I was indifferent to, but other reviewers seem to like it. For me, the story neither helped nor hindered the game. The narration can be turned off.  Highly recommended.
